questions.text:
On a busy day in the casualty at a government hospital, 4 patients are admitted who require the administration of Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), but the quantity of RIG is adequate only for 2 patients. Which of the two patients among the four will you administer the RIG according to priority?
  1. An HIV patient with a category II dog bite on his leg
  2. An 85-year-old male patient with deep and multiple dog bites over his legs and torso
  3. A 6-year-old with a bite exposing the mucous membrane by a dog confirmed to have rabies
  4. A 35-year-old male with a dog bite to his neck
questions.solution:
According to the WHO's allocation of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) according to priority, patients 2 and 4 will be administered rabies immunoglobulin.

If a limited amount of RIG is available, RIG allocation should be prioritized for exposed patients based on the following criteria:

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to highly innervated parts of the body (such as head, neck, and hands)
  4. Severe immunodeficiency
  5. The biting animal is a confirmed or probable rabies case
  6. Bites, scratches, or exposures of mucous membranes caused by a bat

In the given clinical vignette :

An 85-year-old male with multiple dog bites over his legs and torso > A 35-year-old male with a dog bite to his neck > An HIV patient with a category II dog bite on his leg > A 6-year-old with a bite exposing the mucous membrane by a dog confirmed to have rabies

RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine with as much of the dose as possible infiltrated around the wound site.

Rabies immunoglobulin is provided in 2 types and their doses should be:

  • Human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG): 20 IU/kg body weight.
  • Equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG): 40 IU/kg body weight.
  • Infiltrate as much as possible into the wound; the remainder of the calculated dose of RIG does not need to be injected IM at a distance from the wound but can be fractionated in smaller, individual syringes to be used for other patients, aseptic retention given.

 

Note : The rationale for the algorithm of prioritization of patients for RIG administration when it is not available or affordable is based on the innervation of the site involved which is the main factor that determines the incubation and transmission risk of rabies. Hence, patients with multiple or deep wounds and bites to the head, neck, hands, genitals, or other highly innervated areas are of high priority for RIG administration regardless of whether the biting animal is a confirmed or probable rabies case.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 49. His facial features are as shown below. DNA testing is done to confirm the diagnosis. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing moderate mental retardation, long face, and large ears is suggestive of Fragile X syndrome associated with CGG trinucleotide repeat mutation on X chromosome.

The normal FMR1 gene contains CGG repeats. When the number of trinucleotide repeats is excessive, abnormal methylation of the region results in transcriptional suppression of FMR1 and the absence of familial mental retardation protein (FMRP).

Clinical features: X linked disease which predominantly affects males.

  • Moderate to severe mental retardation
  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Large testicles (macroorchidism)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presented with active contractions at 25 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history is uneventful. She is started on tocolytic therapy. A few hours later, she complains of headache, difficulty in breathing, and palpitations. Her vitals and chest x-ray are given below. Which tocolytic agent was most likely administered?

Pulse rate - 122/minute
Respiratory rate - 21/minute
BP - 90/60 mmHg
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of preterm labor. The symptoms of tachycardia, pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on chest x-ray), hypotension, and hypokalemia (palpitations) in the mother after administration of a tocolytic are most likely to have been caused by ritodrine.

Preterm labor and delivery (labor starts before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period) can be delayed by drugs in order to improve the perinatal outcome. A short-term delay of 48 hours allows the use of corticosteroids that can reduce perinatal mortality and serious morbidity significantly.

questions.text: A 66-year-old sopranist in a choir group comes to the OPD with complaints of dysarthria gradually over the last year. Indirect laryngoscopy is done which reveals vocal cords that are bowing laterally. Which type of phonosurgery is performed for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a normal aging process where the vocal cords are lax and bowing for which phonosurgery is performed to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cords.

Lengthening of vocal cords is also performed to elevate the pitch where it converts the male character of voice to female. This is employed in male to female gender transformation.

If someone who has undergone gender transformation from female to male would like to lower the voice pitch, a phono surgery involving shortening/relaxation of the vocal cord is advised. This produces a mutational falsetto.

Medialization of the vocal cord is employed in a completely paralyzed vocal cord where teflon paste or gel foam is used to easily augment and medialize the paralyzed vocal cord to help approximate the opposite healthy vocal cord.

Lateralization displacement of the vocal cord is used to improve the airway.

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

I

Medialization

In complete unilateral palsy (recurrent laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal nerve) - Vocal cord is medialized towards the midline for the opposite cord to meet. Thyroplasty is done by creating a window in the thyroid cartilage and placing silicon or other prostheses to medialize the cord. It can also be used in Abductor dysphonia.

II

Lateralization

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. It creates a lateral expansion of the larynx
and is similar to vocal cord lateralization. Quality of
voice may not be good

III

Shortening (relax the vocal cord)

To reduce pitch

IV

Lengthening (tighten the vocal cord)

To increase pitch

Note to remember: MLSL

questions.text: An employee of an automobile company undergoes a work-place injury where he sustains an injury to his right eye. He is rushed to the hospital and conservative management is provided. On follow up visits, it is noticed that the iris is stained, first greenish and subsequently reddish-brown. Which of the following is the foreign body implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a penetrating wound with the retention of a foreign body exhibiting heterochromia iridis (staining of the iris which changes color) which is caused by iron deposition.

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causes atrophy.

The earliest change is the deposition of iron in the anterior capsule of the lens where oval patches are arranged in a ring corresponding with the edge of the dilated pupil. This eventually leads to the formation of cataract.

In siderosis bulbi, the iris is first stained greenish and later turns reddish brown, causing heterochromia iridis. Depositon of iron in the sphincter of the iris leads to mydriasis.

Eventually, there is retinal degeneration which resembles pigmentary retinal dystrophy. Secondary glaucoma of the chronic type is a late complication and if the foreign body is not removed, it results in blindness as a result of optic dystrophy.

Depostis are revealed by Prussian blue reactions showing an intense blue coloration immediately around the foreign body.

Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical features include the following:

  • Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea.
  • Sunflower cataract- produced by the deposition of copper under the anterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden green in color and arranged like the petals of a sunflower.

Lead becomes coated with carbonates and excites little reaction while zinc may excite suppuration.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was scheduled for a right frontal craniotomy and excision of a brain tumor. Anesthesia was induced, muscular relaxation was facilitated, he was intubated, and the lungs were ventilated. A capnograph was obtained, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.solution:
The curare notch or cleft in phase III or the plateau phase of the capnograph indicates that the patient is trying to breathe spontaneously during controlled mechanical ventilation. The patient's inspiratory effort causes fresh gas to be sucked into the capnometer, resulting in a lower CO2 concentration and a notch.

Capnography is the quantitative method used to assess ventilation during the perioperative period. It provides a graphic representation of CO2 concentrations as a function of time or volume.

A normal time capnograph displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases, with the expiratory phase divided into three distinct components as shown in the image below:

Other options:

Options A and D: End-tidal CO2 is the final value of the exhaled PCO2 curve at the very end of the expiratory phase. Pulmonary embolism shows decreasing end-tidal CO2 (hypoventilation), whereas malignant hyperthermia shows increasing end-tidal CO2 (hyperventilation).

Option C: COPD (and other bronchospasms like asthma) show an increasing upslope of phase III.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic with white corrugated plaques in his tongue as shown in the image. He has been having this for the past 2 weeks and has no pain or bleeding from the lesion. He had been tested positive for HIV 8 years back and is adherent to the treatment. The lesion couldn't be scraped off of the tongue during the trial to retrieve tissue for further assessment. The rest of the examination of his oral cavity is normal. Which of the following viruses is most likely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes oral hairy leukoplakia. It occurs due to reactivation of Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection.

  • Clinical Feature (OHL): HIV-infected patient presenting with white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 
  • Predisposing factors: Immunodeficiency, hematological malignancies, steroid abuse, can also be seen in immunocompetent individuals. 
  • Investigations: Investigations show high levels of EBV DNA in the blood with circulating antibodies against VCA and early antigen (EA)‐restricted proteins.
  • Pathology: Epstein–Barr virus replicates in maturing epithelial cells but is not present in basal and parabasal keratinocytes.
  • Other conditions associated with EBV infection are
    • Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis): fever, pharyngitis, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy
    • Hodgkin lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
    • Burkitt's Lymphoma
    • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
    • EBV‐associated lymphoproliferative disease

 

Other white lesions of oral mucosa:

  • Lichen planus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus
  • White spongy nevus
  • Candidiasis
  • Leukoplakia

Leukoplakia:

  • WHO defined leukoplakia as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.
  • Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. The management includes the elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion.
  • A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long-term follow-up.
  • Specific management includes surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

Speckled Eryhtroplakia has a high-risk of malignant transformation.

Malignancy risk 

  • High-risk lesions
    • Erythroplakia (homogenous or speckled).
    • Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia.
    • Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis
  • Medium-risk lesions
    • Oral submucous fibrosis
    • Syphilitic glossitis
  • Low-risk/equivocal risk lesions
    • Oral lichen planus
    • Discoid lupus erythematosus
    • Discoid keratosis congenita

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was a few hours ago. After resuscitation, the team performs all necessary treatments but the patient, unfortunately, succumbs to death. If you were to perform the autopsy and resect the stomach, which of the following images would indicate the most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
The most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa is denoted by image B.

The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as Magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach, and this is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place in corrosive injury. 

In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus. 

Magenstrasse refers to the pathway acidic agents follow in the stomach, a groove in the stomach along the lesser curvature that is the route food and liquids tend to take in moving toward the pylorus and that is a frequent site of peptic ulcer formation.

questions.text: A 60 kg adult male has a hematocrit reading of 40% and a plasma volume of 3L. What is his total blood volume in liters?
questions.solution:
His total blood volume is 5 liters.

Calculation:

Total Blood Volume = Plasma volume/ 1 - Hematocrit

= 3 litres/ (1-0.4)

= 3/0.6

= 5 liters

Hematocrit is a percentage, as it is 40% which equals 40/100= 0.4

(Normally, Total blood volume is 8% of body weight).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with visual disturbances and fatigue. He finds it difficult to see in the dark for the past few months. There is a tingling sensation in his upper limbs. On examination, there is weakness, sensory loss and dry scaly patches over both lower limbs as shown in the picture, which responds to emollients. The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase.

The clinical features of this patient represent Refsum’s disease and the enzyme deficient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, also known as phytanic acid alpha oxidase.

The given image shows ichthyosis of the shin and the patient complaints of poor vision with extremely affected dark/night vision which is suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa.

It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years. Refsum disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of peroxisomal Phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, an enzyme involved in the alpha oxidation of phytanic acid (branched-chain fatty acid). This results in the accumulation of phytanic acid in the plasma and tissues.

The manifestation of classic adult Refsum disease includes

  • Ichthyosis
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ataxia
  • Occasionally cardiac arrhythmias
  • cardiac conduction defects
  • elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein levels without an increase in cells.

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are normal in this condition.

Treatment: Restriction of dietary phytanic acid (found in dairy products, fish oils, and green leafy vegetables).

Infantile Refsums disease is a distinct entity, which presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features.

The given image shows fundoscopic findings of retinitis pigmentosa characterized by 

  • Attenuated arteries
  • Waxy and pale optic disc
  • Bony pigmented spicules

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with pain in her right wrist for the past 2 weeks. She says that the pain interferes with her daily routine and it has been stressful to nurse her newborn child because of the pain, especially when she tries to lift the baby. She has no significant past medical history and has not been taking any medications apart from her daily vitamin supplements. On examination, she winces in pain when the doctor palpates the base of her right thumb while her wrist is bent towards the ulnar side. Vitals and system examination are normal. Which of the following is the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The presenting feature of this patient's condition is De Quervain's disease which is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL).

It is prominent among females, especially pregnant women. Most commonly thumb is involved.

It is an inflammatory disorder that occurs within the first dorsal extensor compartment. It is caused by reactive thickening of the sheath around the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons.

It is commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. There may be an unaccustomed activity such as pruning roses or wringing out clothes.

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient’s thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It’s the most pathognomonic objective sign. 

It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's tenosynovitis
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome- A tenosynovitis occurring due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor and abductor pollicis tendons, and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Other clinical features of De Quervain's disease include visible swelling over the radial styloid, palpable thickening of the tendon sheath, tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid and pain on resisted thumb extension (hitch-hiker’s sign).

The image shows Finkelstein's test. 

Treatment:

  • The majority of the patients are treated medically
  • Steroid injection and splinting.
  • Only a few require the release of the 1st dorsal compartment which houses the APL and EPB tendons.

Other options:

Option A - Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis is seen in a middle-aged woman with complaints of diffuse pain around the base of her thumb.

Option C - Scaphoid nonunion is seen following a traumatic incident. The patient points to the front of the scaphoid tubercle as the source of pain.

Option D - Intersection syndrome is characterized by pain, swelling, and crepitus over the tendons of extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus 4-6 cm proximal to the extensor retinaculum. It is commonly found in weightlifters, canoeists, and rowers.

questions.text: Mr Suresh visits a hospital with complaints of feeling lightheaded and chest pain. He smokes around 9 cigarettes per day for the past many years and recently he also had admissions to the hospital because he felt breathless. ECG was performed and is shown below. Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts multifocal atrial tachycardia and calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are used in the management.

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT)

In this condition, irregular rhythms arise from multiple ectopic sites in the atria. The exact cause is not known, however, it is commonly usually seen in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.

ECG of multifocal atrial tachycardia

  • Since the rhythms arise from different foci in the atria, it has at least 3 different morphologies of P waves. The heart rate is between 100-150 beats per minute.
  • Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves.

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities.  The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are useful in slowing the atrial and ventricular rates. Cardioversion is ineffective.

Other options

Option A- Long term therapy with amiodarone is also avoided in these patients as it can cause pulmonary fibrosis.

Option B- Beta-blockers may cause bronchospasm, and therefore are not suitable for patients with underlying pulmonary diseases. 

Option C- Digoxin is not found to be effective in the management of MAT

questions.text:
A method of development of drug resistance is shown below. This method is not the primary mode of resistance to which of the following drugs? 
(Extracellular environment - above the membrane, Intracellular environment - Below the membrane)
questions.solution:
Efflux pumping of the drug is shown in the GIF above. It is the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine, mefloquine, halofantrine, lumefantrine, quinine, etc . It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1). 

Ciprofloxacin resistance is developed mainly by reduced affinity to the altered target.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?
questions.solution:
Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis.

It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are:

  • Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis
  • Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing)
  • Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding
  • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

questions.text: A young male patient presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days ago. His blood investigations revealed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy findings are given in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy findings showing encysted spiral larvae are characteristic of Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

questions.text: You notice the following test is being performed by your senior on a 30-year-old patient having an Alvarado score of 7. The patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen on performing the test. What is the name given to this clinical sign?
questions.solution:
The name given to this clinical sign is the Psoas sign.

The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. A score of 7, as seen in this patient, suggests probable appendicitis. 

Various clinical signs have been described which are used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. Abdominal pain with hyperextension of the right hip is known as the Psoas sign. This is because of psoas muscle spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with this muscle. The patient often lies in a posture with the right hip flexed for pain relief.

Other options-

Option (B): Rovsing sign: Presence of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen during palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Option (C): Dunphy’s sign: Abdominal pain on coughing.

Option (D): Aaron's sign- Firm pressure over McBurney's point in acute appendicitis causing pain in the epigastrium, left hypochondrium, umbilical and precordial regions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling and pain in the middle of his right leg. On X-ray, multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions are seen in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given tumors, adamantinoma is the most probable diagnosis based on the above-given clinical scenario.

Adamantinoma is a rare tumor of the diaphysis and presents commonly with pain. It usually presents in the 2nd or 3rd decade and arises from the epithelial cells. The most common site for adamantinoma is the tibia but it may also involve the ipsilateral fibula.

Radiological examination shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and a honeycomb/soap bubble appearance. Histology shows epithelial basaloid cell islands in a fibrous stroma.

Complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice.

The following image shows an X-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI findings are shown in the image below. Considering the sign seen in the image, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI showing a dural tail sign are suggestive of meningioma.

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumour, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases). However, it may also be seen in the following non-meningiomatous lesions such as schwannoma, sarcoidosis, primary CNS lymphoma, metastasis, and chloroma.

The image given below shows axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass and resembling a tail (dural tail sign).

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous, and persistent blush representing meningeal blood supply to the tumor.
  • CT usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI may show capping cysts, vasogenic edema, and a dural tail sign.
  • PET shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand.

Other options:

Option A: Extradural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the skull and dura mater. It appears as a lenticular, biconvex lesion in acute cases or as a crescentic-shaped lesion in chronic cases.

Option B: Subdural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid mater. It appears as a crescentic concave in acute cases or an elliptical lesion in chronic cases.

Option C: Craniopharyngioma is a benign suprasellar tumor arising from squamous epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is commonly located in the hypothalamic region. On MRI, it usually appears as a cystic lesion. It may also present as a mixed cystic or solid lesion. The solid components show intense contrast enhancement.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student comes to the clinic with a history of four episodes of arthritis involving large joints and was recently admitted for new-onset atrial fibrillation. A holosystolic murmur with early diastolic rumbling is heard at the apex. An early diastolic murmur is also heard at the right second intercostal space near the sternal edge. Which of the following is recommended for long-term prophylaxis of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features and a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Monthly penicillin G injections are recommended for long-term prophylaxis.

The findings of mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation indicate the diagnosis of ARF. The presence of atrial fibrillation indicates severe rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis with either oral phenoxymethylpenicillin (250 mg twice daily) or preferably, benzathine benzylpenicillin (1.2 million U IM monthly) is considered the best method to prevent further episodes of ARF, and therefore prevent further valvular damage.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs.

Other options:

Option A: Glucocorticoids are recommended at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg per day (maximum, 80 mg), usually for a few days or up to a maximum of 3 weeks.

Option C: Doxycycline is not a first-line agent for group A Streptococcus, the pathogen that causes ARF.

Option D: Daily aspirin is the treatment of choice for the migratory arthritis of large joints and fever which are common manifestations of ARF.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Act, a patient has the right to choose his caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision called?
questions.solution:
An advance directive, also known as living will, personal directive, medical directive is a legal document in which a person specifies what actions should be taken for their health in case they're unable to make decisions for themselves because of illness or incapacity.

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.
